Learn More & Join Download Assignment PDF Before You Shoot â€¢ Familiarize yourself with your camera's white balance settings. â€¢ Obtain a grey card or a neutral reference card for custom white balance. â€¢ Select a consistent lighting environment for your shoots to minimize color casts. â€¢ Ensure your camera is set to shoot in RAW format for maximum editing flexibility. â€¢ Charge your camera battery and have sufficient memory card space for the session. The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Use aperture priority mode to control depth of field while letting the camera adjust shutter speed. â€¢ Set your ISO to a fixed value of 200 to maintain consistent image quality. â€¢ Explore using the Kelvin scale for precise control over color temperature. â€¢ Understand the implications of mixed lighting and how to adjust white balance accordingly. â€¢ Use the white balance eyedropper tool in post-processing for RAW images to correct color casts. Creative Focus â€¢ Experiment with warming up or cooling down the white balance to create different moods. â€¢ Use white balance creatively to make skin tones appear more natural under mixed lighting. â€¢ Introduce color casts intentionally for artistic effects in your compositions. â€¢ Balance the key light source with white balance adjustments to enhance your subject. â€¢ Consider the emotional impact of color and adjust white balance to align with your artistic vision. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Shoot a series of portraits in different lighting conditions (tungsten, daylight, shade) using auto white balance and compare results. â€¢ Use aperture priority mode at f/4 with ISO 200 fixed, letting the camera set shutter speed; shoot a scene with a grey card to establish custom white balance. â€¢ Capture an outdoor scene during golden hour; adjust white balance settings to emphasize warmer tones and document the results. â€¢ Photograph a still life object under fluorescent lighting with the camera set to its fluorescent white balance preset and evaluate the color accuracy. â€¢ Experiment with custom white balance using a grey card; shoot the same scene multiple times and adjust the Kelvin temperature for creative exploration. â€¢ Use shutter priority mode at 1/250s with ISO 200 fixed, letting the camera set aperture; photograph a moving subject in mixed lighting, adjusting white balance to capture natural colors. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Create a series of images that showcase extreme adjustments to white balance (e.g., very warm and very cool) and discuss the visual impact of each. â€¢ Conduct a comparative analysis of JPEG vs. RAW files focusing on white balance correction capabilities in post-processing. DO / DON'T DO â€¢ âœ“ Do use a grey card to set a custom white balance for accurate color representation. â€¢ âœ“ Do experiment with different white balance presets to see their effects on your images. â€¢ âœ“ Do keep your camera set to RAW for more flexibility in post-processing. â€¢ âœ“ Do take notes on the lighting conditions and white balance settings used for each shot. â€¢ âœ“ Do review your images on a calibrated monitor to assess color accuracy. DON'T â€¢ âœ— Don't rely solely on auto white balance in challenging lighting situations without checking results. â€¢ âœ— Don't forget to adjust your camera settings if the lighting conditions change. â€¢ âœ— Don't shoot in JPEG if you want to correct white balance extensively in post-processing. â€¢ âœ— Don't ignore the impact of color casts from mixed lighting when setting white balance. â€¢ âœ— Don't skip using a grey card when possible; it provides a reliable reference.
